questions.question: How is the normal placenta described?
questions.explanation: A normal placenta is typically described by characteristics 1, 2, and 3.

questions.question: What does a placental cotyledon comprise of?

options.A: Portions of the basal plate divided by clefts
options.B: Portions of the chorionic plate divided by clefts
options.C: Area supplied by multiple truncal chorionic villi
options.D: Area supplied by one spiral artery

questions.explanation: A placental cotyledon is comprised of the area supplied by multiple truncal chorionic villi. It is the functional unit of the placenta. A placental cotyledon or placental lobule constitutes one truncal or main stem villus and its ramifications. Each lobule is supplied by a single truncal branch of the chorionic artery. Each lobule also has a single vein. The lobules constitute functional units of placental architecture. The fetal surface is the chorionic plate. The umbilical cord inserts in the center of the chorionic plate. Note: The entire placenta is supplied by chorionic villi, while each cotyledon is only supplied by a single main stem villus with its branches.

questions.question: Which of the following does not contribute to the prevention of rejection of the fetus?
questions.explanation: Maternal leucopenia is not seen in pregnancy; instead, leucocytosis is seen. This plays no part in the prevention of rejection of the fetus. The fetus is a semi-allogenic graft inside the maternal body, as half of its genes are from the father. Uterine transplantation immunity contributes to the survival of the fetus, despite it being semi-allogenic. This occurs due to the following factors: Decidual natural killer cells are inefficient and therefore are unable to attack the 'foreign' fetal cells. Decidual stromal cells work with natural killer cells to allow trophoblastic invasion. Villous trophoblastic cells do not express HLA antigens and therefore are non-immunogenic.

questions.question: At what period of gestation are the weights of the fetus and placenta equal?
questions.explanation: At 17 weeks, the weights of the fetus and placenta are equal. In the first trimester, the placental growth is more rapid than that of the fetus. By approximately 17 weeks, the placental weight and fetal weight are almost equal. And by term, placental weight is approximately 1/6th of the fetal weight.

questions.question: What is the uteroplacental blood flow at term?
questions.explanation: The uteroplacental blood flow at term is 500-750 ml/min.

questions.question: Which of the following is false about human chorionic gonadotropin?

options.A: Alpha subunit is identical to LH, FSH, TSH
options.B: It causes involution of the corpus luteum
options.C: Maximum level is seen at 60-70 days of gestation
options.D: Detected in serum 8-9 days after fertilization

questions.explanation: Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) does not cause involution of the corpus luteum, but it maintains corpus luteum function. hCG is produced by the syncytiotrophoblasts of the placenta. It is a glycoprotein hormone with two subunits. The alpha-subunit is similar to LH, FSH, and TSH. The beta-subunit is specific and is measured by pregnancy tests. hCG can be detected in maternal blood 8 days after fertilization. Thus, it can help in diagnosis of pregnancy even before the period is missed. Its levels nearly double every 48 hours in early pregnancy, reaching a maximum of 50,000 - 100,000 IU/L by 60-70 days of gestation. Then the level starts falling, reaching a minimum at 16 weeks, which continues throughout pregnancy.

questions.question: Which of the following cannot cross the placenta?
questions.explanation: Albumin and IgM cannot cross the placenta. High molecular weight substances, such as proteins (e.g., albumin, IgM, IgA), cannot cross the placenta, except IgG. Substances which can cross the placenta are as follows: Note: Maternal hormones, like insulin, steroid hormones, and thyroid hormones, cross the placenta very slowly, and only in amounts enough to support fetal development. However, calcitonin and parathormone do not cross the placenta. Substances: O2, CO2, Water, Electrolytes, Anesthetic agents, Immunoglobulin G (molecular weight 160,000 Da), Glucose, Amino acids. Mechanism: Simple diffusion, Endocytosis via Fc receptors in the trophoblast, Facilitated diffusion via glucose transport proteins (GLUTs), Transport-protein-mediated active transport. Lipids: Glycerol, Essential fatty acids, LDL. Endocytosis via specific receptors. Minerals: Iodine, Iron (unidirectional from mother to fetus), Calcium, Phosphorus. Carrier-mediated active transport. Vitamins: Vit A, Vit C, Vit D. Carrier-mediated active transport.

questions.question: A primigravida delivered a baby at term with a birth weight of 1.9 kg via normal vaginal delivery. The placenta delivered appears as shown in the image below. What is this condition known as?
questions.explanation: The given image shows a circumvallate placenta. The membranes at the periphery are thickened and consist of a double fold of chorion and amnion. Normally, the chorionic plate and basal plates are of the same size. In conditions of extrachorial placentation, the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation: Circummarginate placenta - In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage. Circumvallate placenta - In this type, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion. Complications associated with circumvallate placenta are: Preterm delivery, Abortions, IUGR, Antepartum hemorrhage, Retained placenta and membranes. Extrachorial placentation: Decidua, Normal, Basal plate limit, Chorionic plate limit, Circummarginate, Circumvallate, Chorionic membrane, Basal plate, Circumvallate placenta, Fetal surface, Cord, Chorionic plate. Option A: Placenta succenturiata has one or more small lobes of the placenta placed at varying distances from the main placental margins. Options B & D: Placenta marginata or circummarginate placenta - a thin margin is present between the chorionic and basal plates.

questions.question: Following a normal vaginal delivery, the placenta delivered by controlled cord traction appeared as shown below. What is this condition known as?
questions.explanation: The given image shows a placenta with a small, accessory lobe. This condition is known as placenta succenturiata. A succenturiate placenta contains single or multiple accessory lobes. Accessory lobes are attached to the main lobe by a membrane that has a leash of blood vessels. Option A: Bilobate placenta - it consists of two placental lobes. The cord inserts between the two lobes. Option C: Placenta membranacea - the entire surface of the fetal membranes are covered by functioning villi and the placenta develops as a thin membranous structure occupying the entire periphery of the chorion. Option D: Placenta marginata - the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate, and a thin margin is present between the chorionic and basal plates.

questions.question: The USG scan of a multiparous woman at 30 weeks of gestation showed the presence of an accessory placental lobe. Which complication will you not anticipate in her?
questions.explanation: The given scenario of the presence of an accessory placental lobe is suggestive of placenta succenturiata. Preterm delivery is not a complication seen in this condition. Complications of placenta succenturiata include: • Retained placenta • Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) • Subinvolution of uterus • Sepsis • Placental polyp formation • Vasa previa - vessels overlying the accessory lobes can cross the cervix. Their rupture can lead to hemorrhage from the fetus. Note: Preterm delivery is a complication associated with circumvallate placenta.

questions.question: Which of the following types of morbidly adherent placenta is shown in the given image?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows placenta increta. Morbidly adherent placenta occurs due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer. It is of three types: 
   • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium.
   • Placenta increta - villi invade deep into the myometrium.
   • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the entire myometrium and to or through the serosa.
   Based on the adherence of placental lobules, all three types of morbidly adherent placenta can be: 
   • Total - involving all lobules of the placenta.
   • Focal - involving a single lobule or part of a lobule of the placenta.
   Morbidly adherent placenta can lead to torrential post-partum hemorrhage. It is managed via C-section and peripartum hysterectomy.

questions.question: What contributes to the formation of amniotic fluid during early pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Ultrafiltrate of maternal plasma contributes to the formation of amniotic fluid during early pregnancy. Amniotic fluid is formed by: • Early pregnancy - ultrafiltrate of maternal plasma. • Second trimester - the extracellular fluid that diffuses through the fetal skin and thus reflects the composition of fetal plasma. • After 20 weeks - keratinization of fetal skin prevents diffusion across the skin. Hence, fetal urine forms amniotic fluid. Note: Fetal kidneys start producing urine at 12 weeks (8-11 weeks), and by 18 weeks, they produce 7 to 14 mL per day.

questions.question: While performing the USG assessment of a woman at 28 weeks of gestation, you note the amniotic fluid index to be 12.8. When does this parameter reach its maximum value in a normal pregnancy?
questions.explanation: The amniotic fluid index (AFI) is a measure of the amniotic volume, which is maximum at 34 weeks of gestation. The volume of amniotic fluid at each week is variable. The volume gradually increases till 32-34 weeks of gestation. At 34 weeks, it is maximum, and thereafter, there is a gradual reduction till term. Amniotic fluid volume is a passive reflector of the fetal condition. Its volume is determined by the following: Any alteration in fetal homeostasis, caused by fetal and maternal conditions, affects the amniotic fluid volume. Thus, AFI is measured as a part of the biophysical score. Pathway: Fetal urination + 1000-750, Fetal swallowing - 750, Fetal lung fluid secretion + 350, Intramembranous flow across fetal vessels on the placenta's surface - 350.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a function of amniotic fluid?

options.C: Provide nutrition in the form of fat and protein
options.D: Prevent ascending infection to the uterine cavity during labor

questions.explanation: The nutritive value of amniotic fluid is negligible because amniotic fluid is predominantly water. It contains the following: Water 98-99%, Solids 1-2% (Organic, inorganic, suspended particles). Functions of amniotic fluid during pregnancy: It acts as a shock absorber and prevents trauma to the fetus, Temperature regulation of the uterine environment, It distends the amniotic sac and thereby allows for growth and free movement of the fetus. It has no nutritive function, as it is mostly formed by water. Bacteriostatic property. Functions of amniotic fluid during labor: The amnion and chorion are combined to form a hydrostatic wedge which helps in dilatation of the cervix. During uterine contraction, it prevents any interference in placental circulation so long as the membranes remain intact. It protects the umbilical cord by providing a cushion between the fetus and the umbilical cord during contraction. It flushes the birth canal at the end of the first stage of labor and by its aseptic action protects the fetus and prevents ascending infection to the uterine cavity.

questions.question: When does keratinization of fetal skin occur?
questions.explanation: Keratinization of fetal skin occurs at 22-25 weeks. Therefore, diffusion across fetal skin does not occur after this period. So fetal plasma does not contribute to amniotic fluid formation after this time period.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about amniotic fluid?

options.A: Composition remains the same throughout pregnancy
options.B: Major source is fetal urine after 20 weeks
options.C: It is primarily reabsorbed by fetal swallowing

questions.explanation: The composition of amniotic fluid is not the same throughout pregnancy, but changes later in pregnancy due to contamination by fetal urinary metabolites. In early pregnancy, it is identical to plasma in composition, as it is mainly composed of a transudate of plasma. In late pregnancy, as amniotic fluid is primarily formed by fetal urination, the composition is altered. Disorders of the fetal kidney can lead to oligohydramnios. Fetal swallowing is the primary method of resorption of amniotic fluid. Disorders of swallowing in the fetus can cause polyhydramnios. Amniotic fluid is alkaline in nature, and this helps in differentiating it from vaginal secretions, which are acidic. This forms the basis of the nitrazine paper test used for the diagnosis of premature rupture of membranes.

questions.question: A multigravida presents at 34 weeks of gestation with preterm premature rupture of membranes. On examination, the amniotic fluid is golden-colored. Which condition will you suspect here?
questions.explanation: Golden-colored amniotic fluid is seen in Rh incompatibility. This appearance is due to the presence of excess bilirubin in the amniotic fluid due to hemolysis of fetal RBCs. Color of amniotic fluid: Conditions - Pale straw: near-term due to exfoliated lanugo hairs, exfoliated cells from fetal skin; Green: meconium; Golden-yellow: Rh-incompatibility; Saffron: Listeria infection; Blood-stained: post-maturity; Near-term due to exfoliated lanugo hairs, exfoliated cells from fetal skin; Dark maroon: low-lying placenta, vasa previa, altered blood in accidental hemorrhage; Brown (tobacco juice): intrauterine fetal demise

questions.question: Ultrasound findings of a few patients are given below. Which of the following patients have oligohydramnios?
questions.explanation: Among the given options, an AFI of 4.5cm (<5cm) or an SDP of 1.8cm (<2cm) indicate oligohydramnios. Oligohydramnios means an abnormally decreased amount of amniotic fluid (liquor volume is <200ml). It is diagnosed using ultrasound parameters such as: •Single deepest pocket (SDP) - The largest vertical pocket of amniotic fluid identified in the sagittal plane on ultrasound is the SDP. The normal range of SDP is between 2 to 8cm. Oligohydramnios is diagnosed if SDP < 2cm. Amniotic fluid index (AFI) - It is the sum of the deepest pocket of amniotic fluid from each quadrant of the abdomen. The normal range of AFI is between 5 to 25 cm. Oligohydramnios is diagnosed if AFI < 5cm.

questions.question: A 24-year-old primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation came for a regular antenatal checkup. On examination, the size of the uterus corresponds to 26 weeks of gestation and the fetal heart rate is 130 beats/min. On ultrasound, AFI is 4. Which fetal anomaly would you suspect?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of oligohydramnios. It is associated with renal agenesis. Oligohydramnios has the following features: • Fundal height less than the period of gestation • Fetal parts easily palpable • AFI < 5cm • SDP < 2cm

questions.question: A 30-year-old G3P2L2 woman with a multifetal pregnancy is diagnosed with polyhydramnios. What is the amniotic fluid volume required to diagnose it as this condition?
questions.explanation: Polyhydramnios is an abnormal increase in amniotic fluid. It is defined as the presence of amniotic fluid volume >2000ml. Ultrasound parameters used to diagnose polyhydramnios are: • AFI > 25 cm • SDP > 8 cm

questions.question: A lady at 30 weeks of gestation came for an antenatal check-up. On examination, the uterus corresponds to 34 weeks of gestation and FHR is normal. Ultrasound revealed an AFI of 26cm. Which fetal anomaly is most likely to be seen with this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical picture is suggestive of polyhydramnios. It can be seen with a fetus having a cleft palate as fetal swallowing is impaired by this anomaly. Polyhydramnios has the following features: • Fundal height greater than period of gestation • Fetal parts are not well palpable • AFI > 25cm • SDP > 8cm

questions.question: A routine ultrasound of a multigravida at 28 weeks of gestation revealed an AFI of 27cm. Which of the following cannot cause the given condition? a) Diabetes mellitus b) Preeclampsia c) Esophageal atresia d) Open spina bifida. A 28-year-old G2P1L1 at 35 weeks of gestation is complaining of difficulty in breathing. On examination, flanks are full, and abdominal girth is 160cm. Ultrasound determined that the SDP is 10cm. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of polyhydramnios. Preeclampsia is a cause for oligohydramnios, and not polyhydramnios.

questions.question: A female presents with 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation, AFI = 5, and there is no end-diastolic blood flow. What is the management?

options.B: Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks
options.C: Do Doppler every day to check for reversion

questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of fetal compromise. The management in this patient is immediate termination of pregnancy. Since this pregnancy has crossed 34 weeks, it can be terminated by cesarean section. Abnormal flow patterns in the umbilical artery: 
   • Reduced end-diastolic flow indicates uteroplacental insufficiency (S/D ratio increases)
   • Absent end-diastolic flow suggests fetal compromise, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >34 weeks.
   • Reverse end-diastolic flow suggests impending doom of death, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >32 weeks.
   Patterns of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery: 
   Normal diastolic flow
   Absence of end-diastolic flow
   Reversal of end-diastolic flow

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about the umbilical cord?

options.A: It has one artery and two veins
options.B: It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly
options.C: Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies
options.D: Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cms

questions.explanation: The umbilical cord normally has two arteries and one vein. The presence of a single umbilical artery is the most common vascular anomaly of the cord. It is associated with congenital anomalies such as genitourinary and cardiac anomalies. The umbilical cord is a tube that connects the fetus to the placenta. It contains umbilical vessels and an obliterated allantois duct, all surrounded by Wharton's jelly and contained within an outer layer of amnion. Maternal blood enters the fetus through the umbilical vein, and blood exits the fetus via the two umbilical arteries. Wharton's jelly is a gelatinous mucopolysaccharide that protects the umbilical vessels. Local collections of Wharton's jelly produce false knots in the cord. The average length of the umbilical cord is between 40-70 cm at term. A long cord can form a loop around the fetus' neck and can cause asphyxia. A short cord can result in cord rupture during labor.

questions.question: Ultrasound of a 24-year-old primigravida at 20 weeks of gestation shows the presence of asingle umbilical artery. No other gross fetal anomalies were detected. Which of the followingis true regarding this finding?

options.C: It is an indicator of increased risk of malformations of the fetus
options.D: Equally common in newborns of diabetic and non-diabetic mothers73Solution to

questions.explanation: A single umbilical artery is the most common aberration of vessel number in the umbilical cord. Itindicates an increased risk of congenital malformations in the fetus.A single umbilical artery is seen in the following conditions:•Twin pregnancy.•Gestational diabetes/Overt diabetes⚫ Epilepsy• Oligohydramnios• Polyhydramnios• Preeclampsia.• Antepartum hemorrhageIt is frequently associated with congenital malformations of the fetus (20-25%) such as:• Cardiovascular anomaliesGenitourinary anomalies•Trisomy 18It increases the risks of adverse obstetric outcomes like:•• Abortion• Fetal aneuploidy• Prematurity• Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)Perinatal mortality87
